# Description of Data Sources

All of our datasets are stored in our PollutionSight bucket on Amazon Web Services.

* To visualize the amount of deaths worldwide by risk factor, we used data from the 2019 Global Burden of Disease [study](https://vizhub.healthdata.org/gbd-results/).

* To create a multi-layer map containing the CAQI, ozone (O3), sulfur dioxide (SO2), carbon monoxide (CO) and nitrogen dioxide (NO2) levels for specific dates and specific cities, we used JSON data from the historical air pollution API on [openweathermap.com](https://openweathermap.org/api/air-pollution#history). 

* To create a heatmap for worldwide pollution on a globe map, we used OpenAQ JSON dataset for April 2022 containing the values for SO2, O3, NO2, CO, PM2.5 and PM10 from [opendatasoft.com](https://public.opendatasoft.com/explore/dataset/openaq/information/?disjunctive.city&disjunctive.location&disjunctive.measurements_parameter&sort=measurements_lastupdated&%3D&location=6,36.96745,-121.33301&basemap=jawg.light), which consisted of compiled data from different government level and research-grade sources. 

* To perform our machine learning, we used our main data source from [kaggle.com](https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/sogun3/uspollution?resource=download) containing the concentrations of O3, SO2, NO2 and CO in the United States from 2000 to 2016.

* To compare our pollution data with the population of its respective city, we also aggregated population datasets from the United States Census Bureau for [2000 to 2010](https://www.census.gov/data/datasets/time-series/demo/popest/intercensal-2000-2010-cities-and-towns.html) and for [2011 to 2020](https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/popest/technical-documentation/research/evaluation-estimates/2020-evaluation-estimates/2010s-cities-and-towns-total.html).
